item.title: Blockquotes Are Useless And Obsolete
item.author: Alex Wallace
item.content:encoded:
Blockquotes Ugh WHy

They are even worse than the "something considered harmful" cliche

January 20
@amlw amlw is not a real journalist.
Kicker? Kick This Know what I'd like to kick? Blockquotes.

The Internet is awful. Search your feelings. You know it to be true.

Almost every single publisher in the world uses blockquotes, the worst element ever defined by HTML. Yes, that includes blink and marquee and even nav.

Blockquotes are useful in the context of print publishing, where readers scan multiple pages in search of something interesting to read. But on screens, we typically have one article open at a time and we don't skim them. Therefore the only purpose of the blockquote is to repeat a snippet of text that the journalist thinks is particularly "important" - but in reality, it's usually their most hamfisted bit of prose and inserting it in large, bold text simply interrupts the reader's flow, or, even worse, spoils part of the article since the blockquote is repeating text that the reader hasn't even gotten to yet.

Almost every single publisher in the world uses blockquotes, the worst element ever defined by HTML. Yes, that includes blink and marquee and even nav.

Nav is a pointless element because it almost always wraps a list. So instead of the old world where you could use a list with a navigation class on it, now you wrap your list a nav element.

But back to blockquotes. Aren't they the worst?

But back to blockquotes. Aren't they the worst?

Friends don't let friends use blockquotes.
